\(4 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 } \mathrm { J }\)
(b) A constant resultant force \(F\) acts on a car of mass \(m\) .The car moves from rest with constant
acceleration a along horizontal ground.When the car has displacement \(s\) ，the speed of the
car is \(V .\)
(i)Using the concept of work done on the car, show that the kinetic energy \(E _ { \mathsf { K } }\) of the car is
(ii)The mass of the car is \(9 2 0 \mathsf { k g }\) .At time \(t = 0\) , the car is at rest. At time \(t = 5 . 8 \mathsf { s }\) , its velocity
(iv)At time \(t = 5 . 8 \mathsf { s }\) , the speed of the car becomes constant.
given by the equation
is \(1 7 \mathsf { m } \mathsf { s } ^ { - 1 }\)
Calculate the kinetic energy of the car at time \(t = 5 . 8 \mathsf { s }\)
Determine the average output power of the car during this time.
power \(=\) .W [3]
State and explain whether the output power of the car is greater than, less than or the
same as the output power just before \(t = 5 . 8 \mathsf { s }\)
2(a) Define the moment of a force about a point.
(ii)On Fig. 2.2, draw a labelled scale vector triangle to represent the forces acting on the
tree.The weight of the tree has been drawn to scale.
(b) A tree of mass \(2 7 0 \mathsf { k g }\) grows out of sloping ground and is supported by a post, as shown in
image_name_placeholder
The ground applies a total force \(R\) on the tree at point Q.
"he centre of gravity of the tree is a horizontal distance of \(1 . 2 { \mathsf { m } }\) from Q.
The post applies a force \(F\) of \(1 8 0 0 \mathsf { N }\) perpendicular to the line PQ. The line of action of \(F\)
passes through point P at an angle \(\theta\) to the vertical. P is a horizontal distance of \(1 . 6 { \mathsf { m } }\) from Q.
The tree is in equilibrium and allforces act on the tree in the same plane.
(i)By taking moments about point Q, show that \(\theta\) is \(2 5 ^ { \circ }\)
(iii)The tree exerts a pressure of \(1 5 0 \mathsf { k P a }\) on the top of the post.
image_name_placeholder
Determine the surface area of the tree in contact with the post.
3 Two progressive water waves X and Y travel along a straight line from point A to point B.The
variation of displacement of the waves with distance from A at an instant in time is shown in
image_name_placeholder
(c) Wave X and wave Y superpose to form a resultant wave.
(a) State the amplitude of wave X.
amplitude \(=\)  cm [1]
(b) Both waves have frequency \(1 6 H z\)
(ii) State and explain whether X and Y are coherent.
(i)Determine the speed of wave X.
speed \(=\)   \(\mathsf { m } \mathsf { s } ^ { - 1 }\)
image_name_placeholder
(d) The intensity of wave \(\mathsf X\) is \(I _ { \times }\) . The intensity of wave Y is \(\boldsymbol { I } _ { \mathrm { Y } }\)
Use fig.3. terinthra \(\frac { I _ { \mathsf { X } } } { I _ { \mathsf { Y } } } .\)
4 A small ballis dropped from rest from height \(h _ { 1 }\) above the ground and falls vertically downwards.
The ball collides with the ground and bounces back vertically upwards,reaching a maximum
height \(h _ { 2 }\) .Fig. 4.1 shows the ball just before and just after hitting the ground.
image_name_placeholder
The ball has mass \(0 . 2 5 \mathsf { k g }\) and is in contact with the ground for a time of \(0 . 1 8 \mathsf { s }\)
Just before the ballhits the ground,it has speed \(5 . 2 \mathsf { m } \mathsf { s } ^ { - 1 }\) . Just after it leaves the ground, it has
speed \(3 . 6 \mathsf { m } \mathsf { s } ^ { - 1 }\)
Air resistance acting on the ball is negligible.
(c) Calculate the ratio \(\frac { h _ { 2 } } { h _ { 1 } }\)
(a) State and explain whether the collision is elastic or inelastic.
(b) (i) Calculate the change in momentum of the ball during the collision with te ground.
(ii)Determine the average force on the ball during the colision with the ground.
change in momentum \(=\)  . kgms-1 [2]
5(a) Define the Young modulus.
(b) A wire of unstretched length \(0 . 8 1 \mathsf { m }\)  is made of a metal with Young modulus 95GPa. The
wire obeys Hooke's law and has a constant cross-sectional area. Fig. 5.1 shows the
force-extension graph for the wire.
image_name_placeholder
(i)Determine the cross-sectional area of the wire.
(ii)The extension of the wire is initially \(2 . 0 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \mathsf { m }\)
Determine the work done to increase the extension of the wire to \(3 . 0 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \mathrm { m }\)
work done \(=\) .. J [3]
6(a） Define electric potential difference across a component.
(b) A circuit contains four resistors and a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(8 . 0 \vee\) with
negligible internal resistance. When the variable resistor has resistance \(R\) ,the currents in the
circuit are 0.030A, \({ { I } _ { 1 } }\) and \(I _ { 2 }\) ,as shown in Fig. 6.1.
image_name_placeholder
(i)Determine the charge passing through the battery in a time of 4.0 minutes.
(ii) Calculate \({ { I } _ { 1 } }\)
(iv)Determine R.
charge \(=\)  .. C [2]
(c) The variable resistor in (b) is fited with a scale so that its resistance can be accurately
determined.
The resistor of resistance \({ } ^ { 2 4 0 \Omega }\) is now replaced by a new resistor \(\mathsf X\) of unknown resistance.
A galvanometer is connected as shown in Fig. 6.2.
image_name_placeholder
With reference to ratios of resistances,explain how this circuit can be used to determine the
resistance of X.
7(a) State what is meant by a fundamental particle.
(b) A nucleus \(\mathsf X\) has 14 nucleons and \(p\) protons. The ratio of charge to mass for nucleus \(\mathsf X\) is
(i)Determine \(p\)
(ii)Nucleus X undergoes \(\beta ^ { - }\) decay to form nucleus Z.
Complete the equation representing this decay.
(c)A sample of a radioactive substance emits particles that are positively charged and have a
continuous range of kinetic energies.
State and explain whether the nuclei in the sample are undergoing \(\alpha\) -decay, \(\beta ^ { + }\) decay or
\(\beta ^ { - }\) decay.
